review_title: Great place for next-gen wireless enthusiasts
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Guildford, England
pros: brilliant team from diverse disciplines, a dedicated building solely for wireless research, a wide range of expertise, an advanced testbed, and a pleasant atmosphere, it provides an unparalleled workplace experience. Overall, the University of Surrey offers an ideal environment for next-gen wireless enthusiasts to thrive, innovate, and contribute significantly.
cons: One notable downside was the lack of sufficient direction from supervisors. Additionally, the open-plan building layout contributed to a somewhat noisy and distracting atmosphere, making it challenging to focus on individual work. Furthermore, there was room for improvement in fostering collaborations between colleagues, as there seemed to be a lack of structured opportunities for meaningful teamwork and knowledge sharing.

review_title: Worked there in 2009 but couldn't choose that date hope its changed
pros: Worked in the psychology department they were supossed to train me up but I had no training. There were no adjustments even though they knew I was neurodiverse. I got nothing out of my time there and wasted a year of my life. Would not recommend working at University of Surrey would go so far as to say I not only didn't progress but took a step backward after working there.
cons: Staff who aren't interested in taking note of adjustments Staff who hire people who don't need training as they want to pay out less for labour Non existent training programme

pros: Very accepting and tolerant with splendid beauty

review_title: Surrey has a lot of issues to fix and you need to be aware of this
pros:
Colleagues are very dedicated and want to help the university develop
The campus is lovely and the area is beautiful 
There is always something happening on campus, with numerous activities and opportunities
cons:
The management is very afraid of taking stances on issues that might become a problem and you will grow very frustrated if you're looking for a company that challenges the status quo and is actively looking to improve itself 
There have been multiple situations where senior management does not listen to staff members, which led in long-term staff leaving in protest 
It's hard to get your work recognised, with pay and benefits lacking despite of everyone working so hard

job_title: Phd Student Researcher in Guildford, England
pros: Guildford is a great town. Small enough to enjoy a peaceful atmosphere, but close enough to London for adventurous weekends. To university campus is also very lively.
cons: Some research supervisors (my own included) lack knowledge about the field, and like many academics, are interested by what research field is hot and trendy rather than what interests them. But this will ultimately come at a major cost to the student's experience at Surrey. Choose you advisor wisely!

review_title: Overall a very good place for doing research
pros: Flexible working location and time.

pros: Flexible hours, easy money, good team

pros:
Nice location
Excellent vet school facilities
Strive for positive change academically that is evidence led
Excellent support to develop teaching ability via graduate certificate for staff
Excellent colleagues to work with
Overall a great place to work - cons below are relatively minor "gripes" that detract somewhat from the overall experience.
cons:
Workload plans are rarely accurate or followed so individual workloads are high
Induction processes are weak or non-existent so rely on personal initiative to work out what to do
Support and professional services for staff tend to pass the buck leaving academics to make decisions they perhaps shouldn't be
Very heavy focus on students as consumers - better happy than competent
Communication is haphazard - either there is too much resulting in losing key information, or it's too little too late e.g. not telling students something important until the day before it is necessary. An awful lot of time is wasted thinking of the right information to ask for and then trying to find the right place to search for it.

pros: - Generous annual leave - Flexible work - Academic freedom

pros: A good, at first glance, environment to work in.  Most lecturers are honest people. Workloads are reasonable.
cons: The core of the structure operates in a way which does not allow very low or very high marks i.e. if exams are too easy, results will be lowered. If students score low marks, re-marking will take place. There is always a good link between certain sections of students and high ranking academics. For example, students can say "we don't understand her lectures". Then she will have to prove that she is not a bad teacher. When results are released and average mark is above 70%, senior academics will pretend that they did not intimidate you or made you feel not welcome.  The facade works very well.  Many professors have no industry experience or relevant background. In terms of qualifications, many CVs are of debatable quality i.e. although they have obtained certain degrees, these are not "heavy" enough.

review_title: Sports Centre - high turnover, low staff morale
job_title: Client Services Administrator in Guildford, England
pros: The sports centre is treated differently to the rest of the University, so bear this in mind. The Pros of working at the sports centre: great, dynamic and fun people, exciting events, free access to the high quality facilities, staff room, flexible hours.
cons:
No value placed on developing staff
Management do not care about lower levels - they are happy in their high paid jobs and promotion opportunities are rarely available
Due to the high turnover at lower levels, morale is often low
Although part of the University, the sport centre staff get paid at lower levels than those working in similar roles on the campus, which is also discouraging.
Many of our staff have moved to the campus because of this inequality

pros:
Helpful colleagues
Nice campus
Flexible hours for staff with children
Some recent evidence of listening to staff by the Executive Management - which has been lacking in the past.
cons: Constant rounds of restructuring and reorganisation that causes an unsettled atmosphere. Executive Management under the recently-departed VC, do not appear to be listening to staff views and not enough action taken on the staff surveys. One or two of the Senior Management are trying to improve things but not effective as yet. It is all about the "student experience" but the staff are under a lot of pressure due to people leaving and therefore increased workloads for the remaining staff. This may affect the student experience adversely in the future.

review_title: Low Salaries, Too many politics, Good flexibility
pros: I had amazing flexibility and had a great work/life balance. There are good training/learning and development sessions. Lots of annual leave.
cons: Too many executive politics that effect the bottom line, poor salaries and very hard to progress in role or get a promotion without applying and interviewing for another job at the uni. The execs don't value long-term staff. There is high turnover of staff and poor handovers. Workload high. They cut staff and don't replace them, workload gets lumped on others and there is no compensation for it.

pros: Listen to employees, excellent salary package, pension leave allowance good salary. Large company which allows for good career progression prospects. Excellent culture of equality and diversity.
cons: Salaries at the lower levels are above sector averages but as you go up the career ladder they tend to level off and at Middle Management levels although basic salaries are good bonuses are not the sames as in the commercial sector.

pros:
*Proximity to London
*Progressive nature
*Still expanding from a technical university with a small number of arts programmes to a large, diverse university
cons:
*Excessively business-based model
*Overly centralised bureaucracy
*Failure to ever take advice of academic and administrative staff about changes, despite frequent "consultation" periods, and even a pattern of misrepresentation to their own staff
*A historical pattern of overspending, then making drastic cuts, then overspending again
*Despite paying lip service to Learning & Teaching, there is little support for anyone who isn't "REF-able"

pros:
- Generous leave entitlement
- Laid back atmosphere
- Friendly staff and team
- Big campus
- Good courses. LGBTQ+ awareness delivered in House along with other useful courses.
cons:
- Little to no training on SITs - I was free to crash about as I pleased
- Line manager too busy to support new employee/nothing to do in my first 2 weeks. I feel they could've planned for my arrival. 
- HR presence - what HR presence? I didn't even have an induction.
- Nowhere solely for staff to sit away from your main office kitchen. Sometimes I'd rather not mix with students. Someone correct me if I'm wrong please.

job_title: Phd Student Researcher in Guildford, England
pros: Amazing staff, helpful rdp and post grad society. Excellent student union. And great library archive
cons: Slow management, supervisors hit or miss-less rights for PhD students than undergraduate. Weak stipend for researchers. A little disorganised in terms of accessibility and relevant sectors phd students need. For example figuring out who’s the go to for funding advice for international students. Expensive especially for international students during COVID times

pros: University of Surrey is a good place for starting your career but ...
cons: But it may not be what you expect as progressive place for your career! There is not a fair system for recognising your progress or assigning privileges for a good work (who you know is more important than what or how you do)! I do not recommend it for a long term contract, it is a good place for starting your career and then you must move otherwise you will stay in the same level forever!

review_title: A good place to work, with loads of great people. Nice but expensive area to live.
pros: The people and the help that is always on hand. Also there is a degree of flexibility depending on your role, to work from home. As long as the work is being done, not a problem. Quite a few training courses avaliable on a regulary basics.
cons: It is important to bear in mind that Guildford is an expensive area to live. however, its a nice place, and can comute to London easily.

review_title: Good people, but too much focus on league tables
pros: Good colleagues, committed researchers and lecturers with a passion for their work. Location close to train station and easy access to both London and Surrey countryside
cons: A focus on league table position and narrow tick box exercises to measure performance have led to low morale and a general feeling that staff are under valued. Particularly dispiriting to see committed, hard working colleagues put in fear of their jobs. Hopefully this will change with the new management

review_title: Goon on the lower levels, bad in higher levels
pros: What makes the place great to work is the colleagues. Everyone is friendly and a pleasure to work with. Surrey is a great place to live in if you have the money for it (see below) and the campus is quite nice in itself. Support to staff in terms of research is great as well. And the staff at university is really trying to do their individual bests to achieve excellence and a lot of funding and effort is spent on this.
cons:
On the higher levels the policies taken are horrendous sometimes. For example they had this Bonus Scheme where if the university made a profit at the end of year they distributed £70 to each member staff as a yearend of bonus.  I would rather they gave this money to supporting staff (e.g. cleaners or other low paid staff) than to academics which was more like a slap on the face amount to be paid to skilled workers. I think most thought the same as later on they scrapped it and made it a performance related pay scheme, which was equally bad: at the end of the year those who have exceeded expectations in their appraisals received pre-tax 250£ bonus which again came to nothing. Giving such amounts to academics who excel is just laughable. It is more demotivating than motivating.  Academics have high intrinsic motivations and when they want to be recognised for their efforts they want to get comparative salaries to those that are paid in other fields in private sector and not some crumbles.
Another thing I experienced as an international staff member was their miniscule and often selective contributions towards visa costs. While most other universities reimburse visa costs in full (visa+NHS surcharge) and sometimes that of dependents, Surrey only pays for visa cost of the main applicant. Yet we know of many cases where some senior staff members have received reimbursements both for their visas&NHS surcharge + for their dependents... So the policy seems to be quite selective and discriminating. While I can understand university’s aversion to reimburse the full cost of visa and add-ons, the recent policy taken by the university in claiming tax from reimbursements is beyond my comprehension. The university decided to classify visa fee reimbursement as a “taxable benefit” which meant that only 2/3 of the visa cost is now being reimbursed. 

Oh and finally. Expect to pay London prices (or more) and not receive London salaries.

review_title: Overall a great place to work
job_title: Peer Support Specialist in Guildford, England
pros:
Lovely people
Great progression and movement prospects within the business as a whole
Transparent management and pay structure 
Fantastic annual leave and maternity leave entitlement 
Opportunity to accrue time back in lieu 
Decent pay
Yearly staff surveys 
Opportunity to earn Christmas bonuses (where there is spare money in the overall budget and student satisfaction targets are met)
cons:
Can be difficult to progress
The pay differences between those on the lower managerial scales and those in Senior Management is huge 
Decisions are sometimes made without proper consultation of the staff and students it will affect

job_title: Human Resources Systems in Guildford, England
pros: Excellent location, good holiday allowance, nice friendly environment, little stress, predictable work pattern and year, good level of agency and autonomy
cons: Rigid salary bands, non academic staff not always taken seriously by academics, facultys run as separate "businesses" so not always aligned in processes, not enough places for staff to be away from students during lunch, unstructured bonus scheme

pros: Not many, in fact Surrey Sports Park is good but they are bleeding cash just like the university.
cons: Awful culture strife with passive aggressive / non confrontational school leaders. They fake their numbers constantly to get higher rankings however, VC leaving in September they can't pull those tricks anymore. Students are getting angrier. They are on the down cycle now at Surrey. All glitz no substance.  Marketing budgets have been cut now so that rank can't hold. Constant restructuring. Bad and weak business decisions being made in a money losing university will be it's detriment to fail.

pros: Good people and great location perfect work like balance
cons: Politics all over.. you would never know who is your friend and you is envious of you.. Ladies are promoted more than men.. so if you are a guy.. beware of politics..

pros: I worked part-time at the University of Surrey for a year.  Overall it was a very good experience and one of my favourite places to work.  I found my colleagues a pleasure to work with, being hard-working, friendly and committed to providing a positive student experience. My managers were also very good at their jobs and supportive of their staff.
cons: No real cons - wages a bit low in a high cost area.

job_title: Development Research Officer in Guildford, England
pros: Good leadership with clear vision. Excellent perks - childcare vouchers, discounted gym membership, great pension scheme, lovely campus, close to Guildford town center.
cons: Parking can be difficult and is not free on site. There are postcode restrictions regarding who is eligible to apply for a permit and even when you have one, there are days when you are not allowed to park on site.

job_title: IT Infrastructure PM in Guildford, England
pros: The work environment,  the people, everyone is very helpful and willing to take the time to listen.  This is a community where everyone is working together to achieve the same goal.
cons: There is limited parking, on top of that, even if you do pay to park there are also restricted days where you have to park off campus.

pros: I was a student in 2011 at the University and worked part time for them in the marketing department. A wonderful place to work and full of potential for students to pick up part time work.
cons: Mixing studies with the work is challenging. I prefer doing one or the other - full time one place rather than two. Pay is not great.

job_title: South East Doctoral Training Centre Manager in Guildford, England
pros: My supervisors were very trusting of my work and gave me plenty of room to tackle projects that I thought I could handle.
cons: There wasn't much scope for actual career progression. I also had no benefits working part-time, but salary progression was okay.

pros:
Friendly students, professors, staff. Anyone will always be willing to help
Great facilities. Anything related to learning, this university will have it
cons: Learn little of the real world and the "corporate underbelly." (only applicable to my business degree)

review_title: Research Fellow at University of Surrey
pros: Flexible working hours, generous holiday, lots of opportunities for on the job training and development and a very good pension scheme.
cons: Ethics approval system is extremely slow. Onsite parking is also difficult and very competitive at times. Lastly, no health insurance is offered, which has nearly become the standard in a lot of private sector companies.

pros:
The course is well structured with regards to covering the fundamentals
Quality of teaching is very high
Ability to do a placement
cons:

Less scope than other universities for individual projects in first two years

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Guildford, England
pros: working hours are flexible. Possibility to work on interesting projects with companies that are at top of the field. Several labs and workshops to quickly build your prototype.
cons: Slow bureaucracy. Low level of teaching that is reflected in the students who collaborate with you.  Little collaboration among lecturers to try to bid for large, ambitious projects.

review_title: Fine place for a non-challenging but steady job
pros: Part time opportunities around childcare meant that a lot of mums were working at the university. Quite a balanced workforce in terms of gender. Interesting colleagues and events.
cons: Management had been there for ages and were too comfortable

pros: Lovely campus, wonderful environment, good pay and development potential
cons: Only really the parking situation, which is dire!

pros: University of Surrey provides great access to the course I pursue in space engineering. I enjoyed working with high level professor and developed in-depth engineering skill-set.
cons: improved academic skills with basic industrial experience that can be learned by doing in engineering industrial world.

pros: Easy to establish a relationship with researchers in the department. People are very approachable and good at what they do.
